original_data.question: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician’s office. His mother complains that he has been sleeping poorly, and she has noticed that he often scratches his perianal area. A scotch tape test is found to be positive and mebendazole is prescribed. Into which of the following subsets have the naïve T cells (TH0) developed due to the infection in this patient?

model_response:
The TH17 subset of T helper cells is induced by IL-1, IL-6, and IL-23. These cells promote inflammatory and immune responses against pathogens, particularly against fungi and bacteria. The TH1 subset (choice A) is induced by IL-12 and is important in cell-mediated immunity against intracellular pathogens. TH2 cells (choice B) are important in immune responses to parasites and are induced by IL-4. TH0 cells (choice C) are an uncommitted subset of T cells. Treg cells (choice E) are a subset of T cells that suppress immune responses and are induced by TGF-b.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
The skin area around the anus.
A benzimidazole that acts by interfering with CARBOHYDRATE METABOLISM and inhibiting polymerization of MICROTUBULES.
A classification of B-lymphocytes based on structurally or functionally different populations of cells.

Lymphocytes responsible for cell-mediated immunity. Two types have been identified - cytotoxic (T-LYMPHOCYTES, CYTOTOXIC) and helper T-lymphocytes (T-LYMPHOCYTES, HELPER-INDUCER). They are formed when lymphocytes circulate through the THYMUS GLAND and differentiate to thymocytes. When exposed to an antigen, they divide rapidly and produce large numbers of new T cells sensitized to that antigen.

A mature T-lymphocyte that has differentiated in the bone marrow and undergone central tolerance selection in the thymus but has not interacted with its cognate antigen. These cells are characterized by the presence of the T-cell receptor, L-selectin and the IL-7 receptor and the absence of CD25, CD44, CD69 and CD45R0.

An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
